bioghist.p: Philadelphia Memorial Park in Frazer, PA became the final resting place for thousands of burials exhumed from Philadelphia cemeteries. Post WWII urban renewal efforts and increasing development pressures led to the disappearance of some historic city cemeteries. Many of these cemeteries were organized as associations that provided low cost burials to their members - primarily working class residents of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.p: Records include burial and related records for the following cemeteries: United American Mechanics & United Daughters of America Cemetery Association (1848-1918), Belvue Cemetery Company (1885-1954), German Lutheran Cemetery (1874-1968), Union Burial Ground (6th Street Union) (1828-1941) as well as Philadelphia Memorial Park (1930-1950). AUM & UDA records include minute books (1848-1912), account books (1906-1949), burial permit books (1857-1864, 1876-1912), index to interments (1849-1918), etc. Belvue Cemetery Company records include minute book (1942-1949), transfer records for removals from Belvue to Philadelphia Memorial Park, account books (1885-1954), etc. German Lutheran Cemetery records include burial records books (1874-1968). Union Burial Ground Society of Philadelphia (6th Street Union) records include lists of burials, ca.1828-1941. Philadelphia Memorial Park records include book of interments (1930-1950). Also in collection are two currently unidentified volumes recording burials (1884-1954 and 1849-1920).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
